questions.guidance_text: Enter the complete legal name of your business as registered with government authorities. This should match the name on your GST certificate, PAN card, and other official documents. Accurate business name ensures proper policy issuance and claim processing.

Select your business structure as legally registered. The entity type affects your insurance requirements, liability coverage, and premium calculation. Different business structures have different risk profiles and legal obligations.
Specify your business entity type if it's not listed above. Examples include Section 8 Company, Trust, Society, or Government Entity.

Select the primary nature of your business operations. This helps insurers understand your risk exposure - for instance, a manufacturing unit faces different risks than a corporate office. Your business type directly impacts coverage requirements and premium rates.
Describe your specific business activity if not listed above. Be detailed about what products or services you provide.

Provide your complete registered office address where all official insurance correspondence will be sent. Include building name/number, street, locality, city, state, and pincode. This address will appear on your policy documents.
questions.placeholder: e.g., 401, Shree Complex, Andheri Kurla Road, Andheri East, Mumbai, Maharashtra - 400069

questions.question_text: Location of Business Premises to be Insured
questions.guidance_text: Provide the complete address of the business premises you want to insure. If different from registered address, this is the actual location where your business operations occur. Include landmarks for easier identification during risk inspection.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Plot No. 25, Phase 2, MIDC Industrial Area, Pune, Maharashtra - 411018

questions.guidance_text: Enter the year your business was established or incorporated. Insurers consider business age as a stability factor - established businesses often have better risk profiles and may qualify for better premium rates.
Name of the authorized person who will handle all insurance-related communications and decisions. This should be someone with decision-making authority like the owner, director, or senior manager.

Provide a valid business email address for receiving policy documents, renewal reminders, and important communications. Ensure this email is regularly monitored to avoid missing critical insurance updates.
Enter a 10-digit Indian mobile number for urgent communications and OTP verifications. This number will be used for claim intimation and emergency contact purposes.

Your 15-character GST number if applicable. This helps verify your business details and ensures GST benefits on insurance premium. Format: First 2 digits are state code, next 10 characters are PAN, followed by entity code.
Your business PAN (Permanent Account Number) is mandatory for insurance purchase. This 10-character alphanumeric identifier is used for tax purposes and identity verification.

Select the date from which you want insurance coverage to begin. For renewals, this should ideally be the day after your current policy expires to avoid coverage gaps. For new policies, coverage typically starts from midnight of the selected date.
Business Package policies are typically annual (12 months). The end date should be one year from the start date. Some insurers may offer multi-year policies with discounts.

questions.question_text: Is this a New Policy or Renewal?
questions.guidance_text: Select 'Fresh' if you're buying business insurance for the first time or after a gap. Select 'Renewal' if you currently have an active or recently expired business insurance policy. Renewals often get continuity benefits and No Claim Bonus.

Name of your current or most recent insurance company. This information helps in policy portability and claiming continuity benefits. Accurate information ensures smooth transfer of No Claim Bonus if applicable.
The expiry date of your current or most recent business insurance policy. Timely renewal (before or within 30 days of expiry) helps maintain continuity benefits and avoid re-inspection requirements.

Declare if you've made any insurance claims in the past 3 years on any business insurance policy. Claims history affects your risk profile and premium. Honest disclosure is legally required and prevents claim rejection later.

Provide details of each claim: date of loss, type of claim (fire, theft, etc.), claim amount, and settlement status. Include policy number if available. Complete disclosure helps insurers assess risk accurately.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Fire claim on 15/03/2023, Claim amount: ₹5,00,000, Settled: ₹4,50,000, Policy No: 123456789

questions.guidance_text: Select if you own the building and want coverage for the structure. This covers damage to walls, roof, foundation, and permanent fixtures from risks like fire, natural calamities, and other perils. Skip if you're renting the premises.

Enter the current reconstruction cost of your building, not the market value or purchase price. This should be the amount needed to rebuild the structure from scratch at today's construction costs. Under-insuring can lead to proportionate claim settlement.

Select to cover office furniture, fixtures, non-electronic equipment, and fittings. This includes desks, chairs, cabinets, shelving, partitions, and general office equipment. Essential for protecting your workspace investments.

Enter the total current replacement value of all furniture, fixtures, and non-electronic equipment. Calculate based on what it would cost to buy similar new items today, not depreciated or second-hand value.

Select to cover computers, servers, printers, UPS systems, air conditioners, and other electronic equipment. This provides comprehensive coverage including breakdown risks beyond standard fire policy. Critical for businesses dependent on technology.
Enter the total replacement value of all electronic and electrical equipment including computers, servers, AC units, and specialized electronic machinery. Include installation costs where applicable.

Select to protect against losses from break-ins, theft, or burglary. This covers stolen goods and damage to premises during forced entry. Important for businesses with valuable inventory, equipment, or those in high-crime areas.

Enter the maximum value of goods, equipment, and cash that could be stolen in a single incident. Consider your highest inventory levels and valuable items on premises. This becomes your claim limit for theft losses.

Select if you handle significant cash in your business. This covers cash kept in safes, during business hours, and while being transported to/from banks. Essential for cash-intensive businesses like retail, restaurants, or collection agencies.

Enter the maximum cash amount you handle at any time - in safe, during business, or in transit. Consider your peak business periods and largest single-day collections. Separate limits apply for safe and transit.

Select if you have expensive glass installations like storefronts, display windows, glass doors, or decorative glass panels. Covers accidental breakage from any cause except war and nuclear risks. Important for retail stores and showrooms.

Enter the total replacement cost of all glass installations including material and fitting charges. Consider special glasses like toughened, laminated, or designer glass which are expensive to replace.

Select to protect against financial losses from employee fraud, embezzlement, or dishonesty. This covers losses from employees handling cash, inventory, or having financial authority. Important for businesses with multiple employees handling money.

Enter the maximum potential loss from employee dishonesty. Consider the highest amount any single employee or group could misappropriate. Coverage is usually position-based, covering specific roles with financial access.

Select if you have critical machinery or equipment whose breakdown would disrupt operations. Covers sudden and unforeseen physical damage to machinery including repair costs. Essential for manufacturing units and businesses dependent on specific equipment.
Enter the total replacement/reinstatement value of all machinery to be covered. Include installation and commissioning costs. For imported machinery, consider current import costs and duties.

Select to cover laptops, tablets, cameras, survey equipment, and other portable devices used outside office premises. Provides all-risk coverage including accidental damage, theft, and loss. Important for businesses with field staff.

Enter the total value of all portable equipment regularly taken outside office premises. List high-value items separately in remarks. Consider replacement cost of latest models as technology depreciates quickly.

Select to provide accident coverage for business owners and employees. Covers death and disability due to accidents, providing financial protection to affected individuals or families. Shows care for employee welfare and can be a valuable benefit.

questions.question_text: Personal Accident Sum Insured Per Person (₹)
questions.guidance_text: Enter the coverage amount per person for accidental death or permanent disability. Common coverage is 24-60 months' salary or ₹10-50 lakhs. Higher covers may be needed for key persons whose loss would significantly impact business.

questions.question_text: Number of Persons for Personal Accident Cover
questions.guidance_text: Enter the total number of people to be covered under personal accident insurance. Include owners, key employees, or all staff as per your requirement. Named or unnamed basis coverage available.

Select to protect against legal liability for third-party bodily injury or property damage arising from your business operations. Covers legal costs and compensation. Essential for businesses with customer footfall or public interaction.

Enter the limit of liability per incident and aggregate for the policy period. Consider worst-case scenarios like multiple injuries or major property damage. Higher limits recommended for high-footfall businesses.

Select if you have employees to cover your legal liability under the Workmen Compensation Act. Mandatory for businesses with workers engaged in manual labor or hazardous activities. Covers medical expenses and compensation for work-related injuries.

questions.question_text: Number of Employees for Workmen Compensation
questions.guidance_text: Enter the total number of employees to be covered under Workmen Compensation. Include all workers, skilled and unskilled, permanent and contract. Premium depends on wages and risk category of work.

questions.question_text: Total Annual Wages for Workmen Compensation (₹)
questions.guidance_text: Enter the total annual wages/salary of all employees to be covered. This forms the basis for premium calculation. Include basic salary, allowances, and overtime but exclude bonuses and ex-gratia payments.

Select to cover loss of income and increased costs when business operations are disrupted by an insured peril. Covers ongoing expenses and lost profits during restoration period. Critical for businesses with high fixed costs or those that cannot operate from alternative locations.

questions.question_text: Annual Gross Profit for Business Interruption (₹)
questions.guidance_text: Enter your annual gross profit (turnover minus variable costs that would cease if operations stopped). This determines the maximum compensation for lost profits. Review your P&L statement or consult your accountant for accurate calculation.

Select the maximum time (in months) you estimate would be needed to fully restore business operations after a major loss. Consider rebuilding time, equipment procurement, and customer recovery. Standard periods are 6, 12, or 24 months.

questions.question_text: Is the Premises Owned or Rented?
questions.guidance_text: Specify your legal interest in the premises. Owned premises need building coverage while rented/leased premises typically need only contents coverage. This affects your insurable interest and coverage requirements.

Enter the age of the building in years since construction. Older buildings may have higher risk due to aging electrical systems, plumbing, and structural issues. Buildings over 30 years may need additional inspection.

Select the primary floor where your business operates. Ground floor businesses face different risks (theft, flooding) than upper floors (fire evacuation challenges). Basement operations have unique flood and ventilation risks.

Select the primary construction material of your building. RCC structures have better fire resistance and lower premiums. Kutcha or temporary constructions face higher risks and premiums. This significantly impacts your insurance rates.

Select all fire safety equipment installed at your premises. Better fire protection systems can reduce premium by 5-15%. Regular maintenance and certification of these systems is important for claims.

Indicate if you have round-the-clock security guards or surveillance. 24x7 security reduces theft and vandalism risks, potentially lowering premiums. Include electronic surveillance systems if monitored continuously.
Select all security measures in place. Multiple security layers demonstrate risk consciousness and can qualify for premium discounts. Ensure systems are functional and maintained.

Enter the approximate distance in kilometers to the nearest fire station. Closer proximity (under 5 KM) means faster response times and potentially lower damage in fire incidents. This affects your fire risk rating.

Enter the approximate distance in kilometers to the nearest police station. Closer proximity ensures quicker response to theft, burglary, or riot situations. Areas with good police presence have lower crime-related risks.

questions.question_text: Is the area prone to flooding?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if your business location has experienced flooding or is in a flood-prone zone. Flood-prone areas may need additional STFI (Storm, Tempest, Flood, Inundation) coverage with higher premiums. Check local municipal flood maps if unsure.

Enter your total annual business turnover/revenue for the last financial year. This helps insurers understand your business size and calculate appropriate coverage limits. Use audited figures from your financial statements for accuracy.

Enter the total number of employees including full-time, part-time, and contract workers. Employee count affects liability risks and helps determine appropriate coverage for workmen compensation and personal accident.

Upload your current/previous year's insurance policy document (PDF preferred). This helps insurers understand your existing coverage and ensure continuity. Include all pages including schedules and endorsements.
Upload documentation of previous claims including claim forms, settlement letters, or discharge vouchers. Complete claims history helps in accurate risk assessment and faster processing.
Upload your latest audited financial statements or P&L statement. Required for high sum insured values and business interruption coverage. Helps validate declared values and business metrics.

questions.question_text: Any Additional Information or Special Requirements
questions.guidance_text: Share any additional information about your business, specific risks, special coverage requirements, or clarifications. Mention seasonal business variations, expansion plans, or unique business aspects that insurers should consider.
questions.placeholder: e.g., We operate seasonal business with 70% revenue during October-March. Planning to add new manufacturing unit next quarter...

questions.guidance_text: By checking this box, you declare that all information provided is true and complete to the best of your knowledge. You understand that any misrepresentation or non-disclosure may result in claim rejection or policy cancellation.
